items.message: The level of Derwentwater continues to fall but remains high following recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue to affect low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwentwater and the lake frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site today, Thursday 17/02/2022. Flooding of properties is not expected though the campsite itself remains closed. Todayâ€™s forecast is largely dry and we expect the level of Derwentwater to continue to fall. However, levels are expected to rise again in response to further rain associated with Storm Eunice, which is forecast to start in the early hours of Friday and continue through the day. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near Derwentwater and local watercourses, which may be flooded and avoid driving through floodwater. This message will be updated tomorrow, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Westbury, Broadoak and Newnham on the Severn Estuary
items.message:
The arrival of Storm Eunice Overnight on Thursday has the potential to cause severe flooding with overtopping of defences, very strong winds and high waves. There is potential for record water levels along the Severn & Wye Estuary 

Water levels will be at their highest between 7:30 and 11:30 am Friday morning when flooding to properties, roads and farmland is expected. The level at Sharpness gauge is forecast to reach up to 10.8mASD on Friday morning, levels will remain high for a longer period of time due to tidal surge and very strong winds. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and working closely with our partners . Our incident response staff are checking defences.
Please activate your flood plan, and avoid using low lying footpaths and roads during this time.
This message will be updated by 5pm on Thursday 17th February.

The arrival of Storm Eunice Overnight on Thursday has the potential to cause severe flooding with overtopping of defences, very strong winds and high waves. There is potential for record water levels along the Severn & Wye Estuary 

Water levels will be at their highest between 7:30 and 11:30 am Friday morning when flooding to properties, roads and farmland is expected. The level at Avonmouth Portbury gauge is forecast to reach up to 8.6mASD and Newport Gauge could reach up to 8.3m ASD on Friday morning, levels will remain high for a longer period of time due to tidal surge and very strong winds. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and working closely with our partners . Our incident response staff are checking defences.
Please activate your flood plan, and avoid using low lying footpaths and roads during this time.
This message will be updated by 5pm on Thursday 17th February.

The arrival of Storm Eunice overnight on Thursday has the potential to cause severe flooding with overtopping of defences, very strong winds and high waves. There is potential for record water levels along the Severn & Wye estuary. 
Water levels will be at their highest between 7:30 and 11:30 am Friday morning when flooding to properties, roads and farmland is expected. The level at Gloucester gauge is forecast to reach up to 3.9m. This warning has been issued due to the high tidal surge, significant wave height and wind speed which will cause levels to remain high for a longer period of time.

We are closely monitoring the situation and working closely with our partners. Our incident response staff are checking defences.
Please activate your flood plan, and avoid using low lying footpaths and roads during this time.
This message will be updated by 5 pm today, 17/02/22 or if the situation changes.

This warning has been issued due to the high tidal surge, significant wave height and wind speed which will cause levels to remain high for a longer period of time.

We are closely monitoring the situation and working closely with our partners. Our incident response staff are checking defences.
Please activate your flood plan, and avoid using low lying footpaths and roads during this time.

items.message:

Water levels will be at their highest between 7:30 and 11:30 am Friday morning when flooding to properties, roads and farmland is expected. The level at Minsterworth gauge is forecast to reach up to 6.0m on Friday morning. This warning has been issued due to the high tidal surge, significant wave height and wind speed which will cause levels to remain high for a longer period of time.

We are closely monitoring the situation and working closely with our partners. Our incident response staff are checking defences.

items.message:

Water levels will be at their highest between 7:30 and 11:30 am Friday morning when flooding to properties, roads and farmland is expected. This warning has been issued due to the high tidal surge, significant wave height and wind speed which will cause levels to remain high for a longer period of time. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and working closely with our partners. Our incident response staff are checking defences.

items.description: Severn Estuary at Severn Beach, seafront properties
items.message:
Storm Eunice is expected to bring severe gale force winds across the Bristol Channel early on Friday, coinciding with low spring tides. We are expecting this to cause very large and powerful waves along the coast. 
Forecast high water is 08:15 on 18/02/22 with a level of 7.43 mAOD and a Force 9 South Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to properties is forecast at this time and conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect the Severn Estuary from New Passage to the Severn View Industrial Park including low lying properties at New Passage and Shaft Road, Beach Road, Station Road and Riverside Park in Severn Beach. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and liaising with emergency services. Please avoid using coastal footpaths and roads. We will update this message as the situation changes and new information is available.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from 11:45am this morning, Thursday 17th February, and for at least the next 24hrs. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. There is also a heightened risk from overtopping at Haddiscoe New Cut. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 6pm today, Thursday 17th February.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This flood alert for the North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea has been issued as strong winds may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast on Thursday 17/02/2022. Areas most at risk include The North Sea coast from Mappleton to Spurn Point.  Flooding is expected from overtopping waves and spray from 5:30 PM until 8:00 PM on Thursday 17/02/2022. This alert may also be issued on Friday 18/02/2022, as we are expecting stormy conditions on the coast. We are closely monitoring the forecast conditions. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Plan driving routes to coastal roads, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 9:00 PM on 17/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: The flood alert for the Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall remains in force for tomorrow eveningâ€™s tide, Thursday 17/02/2022, between 5:00 PM and 9:00 PM. Strong winds are likely to produce overtopping waves and spray along the coast during this time. The particular area at risk is Kilnsea Village. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. Unsettled conditions are expected over the coming days and it is likely this alert will be needed on Friday 18/02/2022. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated by 10:00 PM 17/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from 11:15am this morning, Thursday 17th February, and for at least the next 24hrs. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads River system. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. There is also a heightened risk from overtopping at Haddiscoe New Cut as the embankment level has been reduced and emergency repairs are being undertaken to bring the embankment back up to condition. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and we will update this message by 6pm today, Thursday 17th February.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:15am and 1:15pm later today, Thursday 17th February. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.54 mAODN at 12:15pm, on Thursday 17th February, which is 0.7m above tide tables, wind Force 6, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). You are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation. There are likely to be further flood alerts issued with Storm Eunice pushing in.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:15am and 1:15pm later today, Thursday 17th February.  The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded.  Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.54 mAODN at 12:15pm, on Thursday 17th February, which is 0.7m above tide tables, wind Force 6, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). You are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation. There are likely to be further flood alerts issued with Storm Eunice pushing in.

High winds are producing large waves and sea spray along the coast as a result of the incoming storms.  First forecast high water is 19:00 on 16/02/22 with a level of 5.88 mAOD and a Force 7 Westerly wind. The second forecast high water is 07:15 on 17/02/22 with a level of 5.60 mAOD and a Force 8 Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. 
We expect flooding to affect the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Flooding to coastal properties, roads, footpaths and farmland is possible two hours either side of the high tides.  
Continuing strong winds and tidal surge will cause larger waves and higher water levels until the weekend.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
We are preparing and closely monitoring the situation. And this message will be updated by Thursday afternoon, 17/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:15am and 1:15pm later today, Thursday 17th February. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.87 mAODN at 12:15pm, on Thursday 17th February, which is 0.81m above tide tables, wind Force 6, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). You are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation. There are likely to be further flood alerts issued with Storm Eunice pushing in.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.74mAOD at 15:00 on 17/02/2022 and 4.60mAOD at 03:30 on 18/02/2022.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 120 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next 24 hours.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 18/02/2022 or as the situation changes.

Tide levels are not expecting to reach alert level for this (Thursday) lunchtime or midnightâ€™s tide. However, with further unsettled weather and Storm Eunice forecast, we are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 to 3 days and as a result we are likely to issue further alerts and warnings. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert and any warnings as necessary. Avoid beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated this afternoon, 17/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
This Flood Alert was issued due to the high tide forecast at 11:30PM on Wednesday 16/02/22, with impacts possible two hours before and after this time. Storm Dudley is forecast to bring strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast.  This tide has now passed.  However, we expect Storm Eunice to affect the coast over the next few days, and with increasing spring tides the effects are predicted to intensify. 
 
The high tide on Friday 18/02/22 midday is also expected to reach Flood Alert level, and we are likely to issue further alerts and warnings over the next 3-4 days, depending on the path of the next storm.  We will continue to monitor levels closely and our incident response staff will be out checking defences and closing flood gates where necessary.  Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. 

We will update this message tomorrow morning 18/02/22 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from St Bees Head to Millom
items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 12:01 PM (midday) today, 17/02/2022. Waves are forecast to cause flooding to low lying areas along the coast from St Bees Head to Millom including Ravenglass and Annaside. The area near Braystones, Nethertown and Coulderton along the foreshore may be affected. Impacts are possible 2 hours either side of high tide forecast, at 12:01 PM today. Tonightâ€™s high tide is not currently expected to reach alert levels. However, with further unsettled weather and Storm Eunice forecast, we are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 to 3 days and as a result we are likely to issue further alerts and warnings. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert and any warning as necessary. Avoid beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated this afternoon, 17/02/2022,or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River and lake levels remain high as a result of recent heavy rain, on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck, and Derwentwater, though they are falling slowly. Flooding is expected to continue to affect low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwentwater and the lake frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site today, Thursday 17/02/2022. Flooding of properties is not expected. Todayâ€™s forecast is largely dry and we expect the level of Derwentwater to continue to fall. However, levels are expected to rise again in response to further rain associated with Storms Eunice, which is forecast to start in the early hours of Friday and continue through the day. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near Derwentwater and local watercourses which may be flooded, and avoid driving through floodwater. This message will be updated tomorrow, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: River and lake levels remain high on Windermere and the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and their tributaries following recent heavy rainfall, and Newby Bridge Sluices remain open. Areas most at risk include low lying areas around Grasmere, Rydal, Ambleside, Windermere, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Today, Thursday 17/02/2022, is forecast to be mostly dry but the lake level in particular will remain raised, and levels are expected to rise again in response to further rain associated with Storms Eunice, which is forecast to start in the early hours of Friday and continue through the day. River and lake levels are expected to remain high over the next few days. We do not expect flooding to properties. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the situation closely and our teams have been out checking watercourses for blockages and clearing debris screens. This message will be updated tomorrow Friday 18/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at all river gauges following recent heavy rainfall. The risk of flooding of roads and farmland remains. 
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. 
Peaks:- Llanymynech peaked at 4.19m overnight.  At Cae Howel the level is 4.16m and rising slowly.
Further heavy rain is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect this to cause river levels to begin to rise again and to remain high into the weekend. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 6pm today, Thursday 17/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Belmont river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford. River levels have risen and are expected to stay high, falling slightly and rising again to similar levels at all gauge locations due to forecast storm Eunice. Peaks: Hay-on-Wye peaked at 2.64m last night; Bredwardine 4.65m early this morning; Belmont predicted peak 4.7m to 5.2m this morning; Hereford 4.3m to 4.6m this afternoon, Mordiford 4.3 to 4.6m this afternoon, Ross on Wye 3.6 to 4.1 this evening. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 6pm today, Thursday 17/02/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Swale, Cod Beck, Bedale Beck

items.message: This flood alert has been issued as river levels have risen on the Lower River Swale around Maunby due to heavy rainfall on Wednesday 16/02/2022.  Areas most at risk include The River Swale and tributaries from Catterick Bridge to the confluence with the River Ure. River levels are expected to remain high during Thursday 17/02/2022. Further heavy rain is forecast for Friday 18/02/2022. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 17/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: The flood alert for the Tidal River Ouse has been issued due to rising river levels following yesterdayâ€™s rainfall in the upper catchments. River levels are rising slowly at Naburn where the current level is 2m, upstream of the weir. The level of the River Ouse in York is currently 2.26m and forecast to rise to a peak of around 2.5 m later on today Thursday 17th February 2022.  Further rainfall is forecast for tomorrow Friday 18th February 2022 and in to the weekend, this is likely to keep upstream river levels high. Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and up to date river levels. This message will be updated on this evening at before 9pm, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: This flood alert remains in force as levels are rising on the River Ouse, due to heavy rain falling on the Pennines during Wednesday 16/02/2022. Flooding is expected to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land most affected, particularly around Riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. The forecast is for a peak around 2.6 m about 4:00 PM on Thursday 17/02/2022. Further rainfall is forecast for Friday. We will continue to monitor levels closely. It is expected that the Foss Barrier will be operated during Thursday. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 17/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at all gauges as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  
Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. River Severn bankfull at White Abbey. 
Predicted Peaks:- Crew Green 5.8m to 6.0m this afternoon, Montford 5.4m to 6.0m overnight tonight, Welshbridge 2.7m to 3.2m Friday morning, Buildwas 3.9m to 4.5m over the weekend, Bridgnorth 3.1m to 3.6m over the weekend.
Further heavy rain is forecast over the next 48 hours which may cause further rises in river levels.  We expect river levels to remain high into the weekend.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 6pm today, Thursday  17/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow, Friday 18/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from St Peters Flat to and including Shoeburyness and the Crouch and Roach estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Crouch, River Roach, North Sea

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:15am and 1:15pm later today, Thursday 17th February.  Tide levels will be high at Battlesbridge and Hullbridge riversides. Creeksea Ferry Road onto Wallasea Island may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.87 mAODN at 12:15pm, on Thursday 17th February, which is 0.81m above tide tables, wind Force 6, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). You are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation. There are likely to be further flood alerts issued with Storm Eunice pushing in.

River levels have risen at the Shardlow river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 16/02/22.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until later this evening.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high and are forecast to rise at the Ross-On-Wye and Lydbrook river gauges following recent heavy rainfall. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye. We expect river levels to remain high for several days. Predicted Peaks: Ross on Wye 3.6 to 4.1m this evening, Lydrbrook 4.3 to 4.8m Thursday night,17/02/22. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 6pm on Thursday, 17/02/22 or as the situation changes.

The flood alert for the Lower River Nidd remains in force due to recent heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include Land around the Lower River Nidd and its tributaries in the area of Skip Bridge. River levels are expected to start falling on Thursday 17/02/2022. Further heavy rainfall is forecast for Friday 18/02/2022. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 17/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels remain high on the River Dee due to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Dee, in particular, low lying land and roads at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. 
The River Dee levels are expected to rise again over the next few days. It is likely that Townfield Lane at Farndon will get cut off as the river rises. We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this alert as necessary. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 17/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge, because of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days, with heavier rainfall predicted over the weekend. We expect river levels to remain high for several days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 6 pm today, Thursday 17/02/22 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. 
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours, and we expect this to cause river levels to begin to rise again.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 6pm today, Thursday 17/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have fallen but forecast to rise again overnight at the Titley Mill river gauge. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is imminent. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Arrow from Michaelchurch to Brierley. Other areas that may be affected include Kington, Staunton and Eardisland. No flooding is currently expected at other locations. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days, with heavier rainfall predicted over the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 6pm today, Thursday, 17/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today, 17/02/22.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. We expect river levels to remain high throughout today 17/02/22. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 18/02/22 or as the situation changes

Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are high and continue to rise slowly on the River Thame following rainfall over the last few days. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 17/02/2022, especially in areas close to the River Thame in the Thame and Stadhampton areas.
 
Today will be mainly dry with a few scattered showers this afternoon. Further rainfall is forecast overnight and tomorrow with the potential to be heavy at times. 

River levels are high but beginning to stabilise around the Thame area. Levels downstream continue to rise around Stadhampton as water makes its way downstream. Levels upstream of Thame do not currently pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff have been in the area clearing trash screens. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this evening, 17/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high on the Middle River Roding as a result of heavy rainfall. River levels are expected to remain high throughout Thursday 17 February. Flooding to roads and low-lying land, particularly around Abridge, is possible. 

Please be aware there are high wind speeds expected in the coming days.

We are closely monitoring the situation, checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from structures.  

You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.
  
This message will be updated this evening 17/2/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Eathorpe river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington.    
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued as a result of Storm Eunice and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Friday 18/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to be affecting low lying land and roads adjacent the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. The Severn Ham at Tewkesbury starts to fill. Predicted peaks:- Mythe 3m to 3.2m today,17/02/22. River levels are expected to remain high for some time. More rain is forecast over the next few days that may cause river levels to rise further. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 17:00 on 17/02/22, or as the situation changes.

Storm Eunice is expected to bring severe gale force winds across the Bristol Channel early on Friday, coinciding with low spring tides. We are expecting this to cause very large and powerful waves along the coast. 
Forecast high water is 08:15 on 18/02/22 with a level of 7.43 mAOD and a Force 9 South Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  
We expect flooding to affect the Severn Estuary at Severn Beach including New Passage and Pilning.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and liaising with emergency services.  
Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
We will update this message as the situation changes and new information is available.

Tide levels are not expecting to reach alert level for this (Thursday) lunchtime or midnightâ€™s tide. However, with further unsettled weather and Storm Eunice forecast, we are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 to 3 days and as a result we are likely to issue further alerts and warnings. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert and any warnings as necessary. Avoid beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated this afternoon, 17/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Buxton river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 16/02/22. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Ashford and Bakewell areas, and the A6 at Buxton.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
The arrival of Storm Eunice Overnight on Thursday has the potential to cause severe flooding with overtopping of defences, very strong winds and high waves. There is potential for record water levels along the Severn & Wye estuaries.  
There is likely to be severe impacts to communities along the Severn & Wye, with people and property affected on Friday morning over the high tide period. 
Please stay away from the Estuary and implement your flood plan. Please avoid low lying roads and footpaths during this time. 
There is potential for high water levels between 7:30 and 11:30 am Friday morning
Please stay alert as flood warnings will be issued for your community tomorrow morning.
This message will be superseded by flood warnings.

The arrival of Storm Eunice Overnight on Thursday has the potential to cause severe flooding with overtopping of defences, very strong winds and high waves. There is potential for record water levels along the Severn & Wye estuaries.  
There is likely to be severe impacts to communities along the Severn & Wye, with people and property affected on Friday morning over the high tide period. 
Please stay away from the Estuary and implement your flood plan. Please avoid low lying roads and footpaths during this time. 
There is potential for high water levels between 7:30 and 11:30 am Friday morning
Please stay alert as flood warnings will be issued for your community tomorrow morning.
This message will be superseded by flood warnings.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are high but within banks on the River Ray. Levels are gradually rising as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying roads and farmland is possible this afternoon, 17/02/2022, and in the areas around Islip.

Today will be mainly dry with a few scattered showers this afternoon. Further rainfall is forecast overnight and tomorrow with the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to continue to slowly rise this morning before stabilising this afternoon. Levels are currently within banks but remain sensitive to further rainfall.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be in the area clearing trash screens. 

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this evening, 17/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert was issued due to the high tide and waves forecast at 11:30 PM on Wednesday, 16/02/2022. 
This tide has now passed.  However, we expect Storm Eunice to affect the coast over the next few days, and with increasing spring tides, the effects are predicted to intensify.

We are expecting to reach Flood Alert level again at the midday high tide on Friday, 18/02/2022, and we are likely to issue further alerts and warnings over the next 3-4 days, depending on the path of the next storm.
We will continue to monitor levels closely and our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning on 18/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Cornwall coast from The Rumps to Hartland Point excluding Bude
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the morning and evening high tides on Friday 18th February. High water at Padstow is at 6.21am and 6.41pm, times of high water will vary along the coast.

Storm force 10 west-southwesterly winds and offshore wave heights up to 9m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations including Port Quin, Port Isaac, Trebarwith Strand and Boscastle.
Expect the high tide on Friday morning to be up to 740mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions. Coastal conditions are expected to ease slightly for Friday eveningâ€™s high tide, but remain above flood alert criteria.

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required. Further flood warnings may be required over this period.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; the forecast high tide level at Padstow on Friday morning is 4.06 mAOD, this is 0.47 metres above astronomical tide level.

Expect the high tide on Friday morning to be around 480mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions. Coastal conditions are expected to ease slightly for Friday eveningâ€™s high tide, but remain above flood alert criteria.

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Storm Eunice is expected to bring severe gale force winds across the Bristol Channel early on Friday, coinciding with low spring tides and causing a tidal surge that could overtop sea defences. 
Forecast high water is 08:15 on 18/02/22 with a level of 7.43 mAOD and a Force 9 South Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  
We expect flooding to affect the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.   
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
We will update this message as the situation changes and new information is available.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high tides coinciding with high river levels.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible tonight, 17/02/22.  Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.   
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 18/02/22 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Dunster Beaches, Blue Anchor, Steart, Stolford and Brean
items.message:
Storm Eunice is expected to bring severe gale force winds across the Somerset coast early Friday and into Saturday, coinciding with spring tides. We are expecting this to cause very large and powerful waves along the coast. And sea spray may overtop sea defences. First forecast high water is 07:45 on 18/2/22 with a level of 6.7 mAOD and a Force 8 South-westerly wind. Second forecast high water is 20:00 on 18/2/22 with a level of 6.2 mAOD and a Force 7 South-westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point; mAOD is height above average sea level; for more detail refer to local tide tables. 
Flooding to coastal properties, roads, footpaths and farmland is possible two to three hours either side of the high tides. Please be careful and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.
Coastal conditions should ease for the high tide at 08:30 on Saturday,19/2/22.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and we are closely monitoring the situation.  
We will update this message as the situation changes and new information is available.

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk

items.message:
River levels are now falling and are expected to continue to fall overnight and into tomorrow, Thursday 17th February. 
On Friday (February 18th) Storm Eunice is expected to bring further heavy rain and snow, as well as very strong winds.  Given the stormy conditions, stay well away from watercourses and be aware of debris and surface water affecting roads. We are closely monitoring the forecast and will issue further flood alerts and warnings if necessary, over the next few days.

River Levels in the Upper River Aire have now fallen below the flood risk threshold and are no longer filling the washlands. As there is no further significant rainfall forecast today, Thursday 17th February. Washlands at Snaygill Ings, Skipton and Cononley are draining steadily but will still contain water for some time as this process takes place. 

On Friday Storm Eunice is expected to bring further heavy rain and snow, as well as very strong winds.  Given the stormy conditions, stay well away from watercourses and flood water and be aware of debris and surface water affecting roads. We are closely monitoring the forecast and will issue further flood alerts and warnings if necessary over the next few days.
